threads.com:
Coffee Is My Water edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For poorly sleeping fatties who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>69081663
>How do I recover faster so I can train more?
>why do you need to train more?
Let me clarify before a bunch of shitters reply: I'm an athlete and I need to reach my peak genetic potential in 6 months.
You've got it backwards. The only reason to strength train is to get bigger and stronger. Recovering faster so you can train more simply for the sake of training more is counterproductive. Train, recover, supercompensate, then train again once the gains have been milked. You're probably training too much already if you go more 3x a week or more on the same body part. You want to be in top physical condition? 2x a week on the same body part OR LESS (if you're not on steroids) with far more rest than you think is necessary. If you're not getting stronger in every single workout then you need to rest more. Stop training 10 days before whatever event you're doing in order to be fully recovered and at peak physical condition at that specific time. Cycle with 6-8 weeks of training, followed by 10 days of rest (no exercise whatsoever on any body part), followed by 6-8 more weeks of training and repeat. Expect 15%-20% increases in size and strength over a 6 week cycle if you train 3x per week. Gains are going to be roughly the same or slightly better if you do less.

On days that you do skill specific sport training, don't incorporate any lifts. When you do sport training, only practice the skills that you will need to use in order to perform the sport. Skill doesn't transfer. You have to do the exact movements that you would in sport to get the neurological muscle memory benefits of having practiced.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/e/2PACX-1vRLVvEbt6ynpuBei0AIC0uMtq0v-sOna7FxSOpQ8ZvS2GDyVqlFdeQ7WROKap2VSv67qQOq_8g1XYCP/pub

>Advice for new runners
- Try to keep your cadence high (at or around 180 steps per minute)
- Try to keep your heartrate in Zone1/2 (around an average of 55-65% of your max. heart rate)
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- If you can comfortably run 6 miles at one time, start thinking about what your goal race is, and look for a training routine for that race.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>69079946
Yes. you are likely experiencing general back fatigue, its tired and need some rest. Feelings of stiffness tends to come from two things, one being long time of inactivity like only sitting or lying down with little to no movement and exercise, the other thing is accumulated fatigue from training it tends to manifest as stiffness and tightness and pain. The third is doing higher loads or volume in single sessions that are above current tolerate capacity (acute fatigue)

>Howeverrrrr, the fucking stiffness is suddenly gone. I mean what fucking gives?
You are reading to much in to this trying to derive info out of what is essentially noise. Many people new to fitness do this kind of thing and end up down some long roads of misinformation. Do your self a favore and read this and avoid years of wasted effort based on faulty understandings and conceptions about pain and injury
https://www.barbellmedicine.com/blog/pain-and-movement-caught-in-an-endless-loop-of-misinformation/
https://www.barbellmedicine.com/blog/catastrophizing/
https://www.barbellmedicine.com/blog/on-beliefs-vs-evidence/
